content.question: The total number of reported cases of an illness in a large city <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> days after the start of an outbreak is modeled by the function <math alttext="y equals, F of t " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>F</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that is a solution to the logistic differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction 1 over 5600, end fraction, times y, times, open parenthesis, 1400 minus y, close parenthesis " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>5600</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1400</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. If there are 5 reported cases of the illness initially, what is the limiting value for the total number of reported cases of the illness as <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increases?

topic.text: 7.9: (BC ONLY) Logistic Models with Differential Equations

skill.text: Skill 3.F: Explain the meaning of mathematical solutions in context.
